castItem.roleDesc: Mucedorus is Prince of Valencia.
Amadine is the daughter of the King of Aragon.
Lord Segasto is Amadine’s suitor.
Mouse is a local peasant also known as “Clown”.
Bremo is known as the wild man of the forest.
The King of Aragon is Amadine’s father.
Comedy is the character representing “Comedy” in the play.
Envy is the character representing “Envy” in the play.
The King of Valencia is Mucedorus’ father.
Anselmo is a friend of Mucedorus.
Prologue is a speaker who starts the play with an oration praising the sacred majesty who rules England.
Collin serves as an advisor to the King of Aragon.
Tremelio is a captain in the King of Aragon’s army.
Rumbelo is a servant of Lord Segasto.
A courtier in the service of the King of Valencia.
Ariena is Amadine’s maid.
A Messenger reports to Mucedorus that he has been banished by the King of Aragon.
A Catalonian prince captured in battle.
Lord Barachius is a nobleman in the court of the King of Valencia.
The Boy carries into court the head of the bear killed by Mucedorus.
A Bear is slain by Mucedorus when he sees it attacking Amadine.

sp.speaker: PRO.
sp.l: Most sacred majesty, whose great deserts
Thy subject England, nay, the world admires,
Which heaven grant still increase: O may your praise,
Multiplying with your hours, your fame still raise,
Embrace your Council, love with faith them guide
That both, as one bench by each other’s side,
So may your life pass on and run so even
That your firm zeal plant you a throne in heaven,
Where smiling angels shall your guardians be
From blemished traitors stained with perjury.
And, as the night’s inferior to the day,
So be all earthly regions to your sway:
Be as the sun to day, the day to night,
For from your beams Europe shall borrow light:
Mirth drown your bosom, fair delight your mind
And may our pastime your contentment find.

stage.dir: Enter Comedy joyfully with a garland of bays on her head.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Why so? Thus do I hope to please!
Music revives and mirth is tolerable:
Comedy, play thy part and please,
Make merry them that comes to joy with thee:
Joy then, good gentles, I hope to make you laugh.
Sound forth Bellona’s silver tunèd strings.
Time fits us well, the day and place is ours.

stage.dir: Enter Envy, his arms naked, besmeared with blood.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Nay stay, minion, there lies a block:
What all on mirth? I’ll interrupt your tale
And mix your music with a tragic end.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: What monstrous ugly hag is this,
That dares control the pleasures of our will?
Vaunt, churlish cur, besmeared with gory blood
That seem’st to check the blossom of delight
And stiff the sound of sweet Bellona’s breath.
Blush, monster, blush, and post away with shame,
That seek’st disturbance of a goddess’ deeds.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Post hence thyself, thou counterchecking trull,
I will possess this habit spite of thee
And gain the glory of thy wishèd port.
I’ll thunder music shall appall the nymphs
And make them shiver their clattering strings,
Flying for succor to their dankish caves.

stage.dir: Sound drums within and cry, ‘Stab, stab!’.

sp.l: Hearken, thou shalt hear a noise
Shall fill the air with a shrilling sound,
And thunder music to the gods above:
Mars shall himself breathe down
A peerless crown upon brave Envy’s head,
And raise his chival with a lasting fame.
In this brave music Envy takes delight,
Where I may see them wallow in their blood
To spurn at arms and legs quite shivered off,
And hear the cries of many thousand slain.
How lik’st thou this, my trull? This sport alone for me.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Vaunt, bloody cur, nursed up with tiger’s sap,
That so dost seek to quail a woman’s mind.
Comedy is mild, gentle, willing for to please
And seeks to gain the love of all estates,
Delighting in mirth, mixed all with lovely tales,
And bringeth things with treble joy to pass.
Thou, bloody, envious disdainer of men’s joys,
Whose name is fraught with bloody stratagems,
Delights in nothing but in spoil and death,
Where thou mayst trample in their lukewarm blood
And grasp their hearts within thy cursèd paws.
Yet vail thy mind, revenge thou not on me:
A silly woman begs it at thy hands,
Give me the leave to utter out my play,
Forbear this place, I humbly crave thee hence,
And mix not death ’mongst pleasing comedies,
That treats nought else but pleasure and delight.
If any spark of human rests in thee,
Forbear, begone, tender the suit of me.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Why, so I will: forbearance shall be such
As treble death shall cross thee with despite
And make thee mourn where most thou joyest,
Turning thy mirth into a deadly dole,
Whirling thy pleasures with a peal of death,
And drench thy methods in a sea of blood.
This will I do! Thus shall I bear with thee,
And more, to vex thee with a deeper spite,
I will with threats of blood begin thy play,
Favoring thee with envy and with hate.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Then, ugly monster, do thy worst!
I will defend them in despite of thee
And though thou think’st with tragic fumes
To brave my play unto my deep disgrace,
I force it not: I scorn what thou canst do.
I’ll grace it so, thyself shall it confess
From tragic stuff to be a pleasant comedy.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Why then, Comedy, send thy actors forth
And I will cross the first steps of their trade:
Making them fear the very dart of death.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: And I’ll defend them maugre all thy spite
So, ugly fiend, farewell, till time shall serve
That we may meet to parley for the best.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Content, Comedy, I’ll go spread my branch.
And scattered blossoms from mine envious tree
Shall prove two monsters, spoiling of their joys.

scene.scenelocation: An apartment at the court of the King of Valencia.

stage.dir: Sound. Enter Mucedorus and Anselmo, his friend.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Anselmo?

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: My lord and friend.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: True, my Anselmo, both thy lord and friend,
Whose dear affections bosom with my heart
And keep their domination in one orb.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Whence ne’er disloyalty shall root it forth,
But faith plant firmer in your choice respect.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Much blame were mine if I should other deem,
Nor can coy fortune contrary allow.
But, my Anselmo, loath I am to say,
I must estrange that friendship —
Misconster not, ’tis from the realm, not thee:
Though lands part bodies, hearts keep company.
Thou know’st that I imparted often have
Private relations with my royal sire,
Had as concerning beauteous Amadine,
Rich Aragon’s bright jewel, whose face — some say —
That blooming lilies never shone so gay,
Excelling not excelled: yet lest report
Does mangle verity, boasting of what is not,
Winged with desire, thither I’ll straight repair,
And be my fortunes as my thoughts are, fair.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Will you forsake Valencia, leave the court,
Absent you from the eye of sovereignty?
Do not, sweet prince, adventure on that task,
Since danger lurks each-where: be won from it.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Desist dissuasion:
My resolution brooks no battery,
Therefore, if thou retain thy wonted form,
Assist what I intend.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Your miss will breed a blemish in the court,
And throw a frosty dew upon that beard
Whose front Valencia stoops to.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: If thou my welfare tender, then, no more!
Let love’s strong magic charm thy trivial phrase,
Wasted as vainly as to gripe the sun.
Augment not then more answers: lock thy lips,
Unless thy wisdom suit me with disguise
According to my purpose.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: That action craves no counsel,
Since what you rightly are will more command
Than best usurpèd shape.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thou still art opposite in disposition,
A more obscure, servile habiliment
Beseems this enterprise.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Then like a Florentine or mountebank?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: ’Tis much too tedious, I dislike thy judgment,
My mind is grafted on an humbler stock.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Within my closet does there hang a cassock,
Though base the weed is: ’twas a shepherd’s
Which I presented in Lord Julio’s masque.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: That, my Anselmo, and none else but that
Mask Mucedorus from the vulgar view.
That habit suits my mind: fetch me that weed.
Better than kings have not disdained that state,
And much inferior to obtain their mate.

stage.dir: Enter Anselmo with a shepherd’s coat.

sp.l: So, let our respect command thy secrecy:
At once a brief farewell,
Delay to lovers is a second hell.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Prosperity forerun thee, awkward chance
Never be neighbor to thy wish’s venture:
Content and fame advance thee, ever thrive
And glory thy mortality survive.

scene.scenelocation: The outskirts of a forest near Aragon.

stage.dir: Enter Mouse with a bottle of hay.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, horrible, terrible! Was ever poor gentleman so scared out of his seven senses? A bear? Nay, sure it cannot be a bear, but some devil in a bear’s doublet: for a bear could never have had that agility to have frighted me. Well, I’ll see my father hanged before I’ll serve his horse any more. Well, I’ll carry home my bottle of hay, and for once make my father’s horse turn puritan and observe fasting days, for he gets not a bit. But soft: this way she followed me, therefore I’ll take the other path and because I’ll be sure to have an eye on her, I will take hands with some foolish creditor and make every step backward.

stage.dir: As he goes backwards, the bear comes in, and he tumbles over her, and runs away, and leaves his bottle of hay behind him.
Enter Segasto running and Amadine after him, being pursued with a bear.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: O, fly, madam, fly or else we are but dead.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Help, Segasto, help! Help, sweet Segasto, or else I die!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Alas, madam, there is no way but flight,
Then haste and save yourself.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Why then I die. Ah, help me in distress!

stage.dir: Enter Mucedorus like a shepherd with a sword drawn and a bear’s head in his hand.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Stay, lady, stay, and be no more dismayed.
That cruel beast most merciless and fell,
Which have bereaved thousands of their lives,
Affrighted many with his hard pursues,
Prying from place to place to find his prey.
Prolonging thus his life by others’ death,
His carcass now lies headless, void of breath.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: That foul deformèd monster, is he dead?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Assure yourself thereof, behold his head:
Which if it please you, lady, to accept,
With willing heart I yield it to your majesty.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Thanks, worthy shepherd, thanks a thousand times
This gift assure thyself contents me more,
Than greatest bounty of a mighty prince,
Although he were the monarch of the world.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Most gracious goddess, more than mortal wight —
Your heavenly hue of right imports no less —
Most glad am I, in that it was my chance
To undertake this enterprise in hand,
Which doth so greatly glad your princely mind.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: No goddess, shepherd, but a mortal wight —
A mortal wight distressèd as thou see’st.
My father here is king of Aragon:
I, Amadine, his only daughter am
And after him sole heir unto the crown.
Now whereas it is my father’s will
To marry me unto Segasto,
On whose wealth through father’s former usury
Is known to be no less than wonderful.
We both of custom oftentimes did use —
Leaving the court — to walk within the fields
For recreation especially the spring.
In that it yields great store of rare delights.
And passing further than our wonted walks.
Scarce entered were within these luckless woods.
But right before us down a steep-fall hill
A monstrous ugly bear did hie him fast
To meet us both — I faint to tell the rest.
Good shepherd, but suppose the ghastly looks.
The hideous fears, the thousand hundred woes,
Which at this instant Amadine sustained.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Yet, worthy princess, let thy sorrow cease.
And let this sight your former joys revive.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Believe me, shepherd, so it doth no less.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Long may they last unto your heart’s content.
But tell me, lady what is become of him,
Segasto called, what is become of him?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I know not, I: that know the powers divine:
But God grant this, that sweet Segasto live.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Yet hard-hearted he in such a case,
So cowardly to save himself by flight
And leave so brave a princess to the spoil.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Well, shepherd, for thy worthy valor tried,
Endangering thyself to set me free,
Unrecompensed sure thou shalt not be.
In court thy courage shall be plainly known:
Throughout the kingdom will I spread thy name,
To thy renown and never-dying fame:
And that thy courage may be better known,
Bear thou the head of this most monstrous beast
In open sight to every courtier’s view:
So will the king my father thee reward.
Come let’s away, and guard me to the court.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: With all my heart!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: When heaps of harms do hover overhead,
’Tis time as then, some say, to look about
And of ensuing harms to choose the least:
But hard, yea hapless, is that wretch’s chance,
Luckless his lot and caitiff-like accursed.
At whose proceedings Fortune ever frowns:
Myself I mean, most subject unto thrall,
For I, the more I seek to shun the worst,
The more by proof I find myself accursed.
Erewhiles assaulted with an ugly bear —
Fair Amadine in company all alone —
Forthwith by flight I thought to save myself,
Leaving my Amadine unto her shifts,
For death it was for to resist the bear
And death no less of Amadine’s harms to hear.
Accursèd I in ling’ring life thus long!
In living thus each minute of an hour
Doth pierce my heart with darts of thousand deaths:
If she by flight her fury do escape,
What will she think?
Will she not say, yea, flatly to my face.
Accusing me of mere disloyalty,
‘A trusty friend is tried in time of need’?
But I, when she in danger was of death,
And needed me and cried, ‘Segasto, help!’
I turned my back and quickly ran away.
Unworthy I to bear this vital breath!
But what, what needs these plaints?
If Amadine do live then happy I.
She will in time forgive and so forget:
Amadine is merciful, not Juno-like
In harmful heart to harbor hatred long.

stage.dir: Enter Mouse, the Clown, running crying ‘Clubs!’.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Clubs, prongs, pitchforks, bills, O, help! A bear, a bear, a bear!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Still bears, and nothing else but bears! Tell me, sirrah, where she is.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O sir, she is run down the woods: I saw her white head and her white belly.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thou talkest of wonders, to tell me of white bears. But, sirrah, didst thou ever see any such?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: No faith, I never saw any such but I remember my father’s words: he bade me take heed I was not caught with a white bear.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: A lamentable tale no doubt!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I tell you what, sir, as I was going a-field to serve my father’s great horse, and carried a bottle of hay upon my head, now do you see, sir, I, fast hoodwinked, that I could see nothing. I, perceiving the bear coming, I threw my hay into the hedge and ran away.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: What, from nothing?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I warrant you, yes. I saw something, for there was two load of thorns besides my bottle of hay, and that made three.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: But tell me, sirrah, the bear that thou didst see, did she not bear a bucket on her arm?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ha ha, ha! I never saw bear go a-milking in all my life. But hark you, sir, I did not look so high as her arm: I saw nothing but her white head and her white belly.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: But tell me, sirrah, where dost thou dwell?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why no! How should I know thee?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why then you know nobody and you know not me. I tell you, sir, I am the goodman rat’s son of the next parish over the hill.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Goodman Ratson! Why, what’s thy name?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, I am very near kin unto him.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I think so, but what’s thy name?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: My name? I have very pretty name. I’ll tell you what my name is: my name is Mouse.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: What, plain Mouse?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ay, plain mouse without either welt or guard. But do you hear, sir, I am but a very young mouse, for my tail is scarce grown out yet: look you here else.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: But I pray thee, who gave thee that name?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Faith, sir, I know not that, but if you would fain know, ask my father’s great horse, for he hath been half a year longer with my father than I have.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: This seems to be a merry fellow,
I care not if I take him home with me:
Mirth is a comfort to a troubled mind,
A merry man, a merry master makes!
How say’st thou, sirrah, wilt thou dwell with me?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay soft, sir, two words to a bargain: pray you what occupation are you?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: No occupation: I live upon my lands.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Your lands? Away! You are no master for me, why do you think that I am so mad to go seek my living in the lands amongst the stones, briars and bushes, and tear my holiday apparel? Not I, by your leave.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, I do not mean thou shalt.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why thou shalt be my man and wait upon me at the court.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What’s that?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Where the king lies.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What’s that same king, a man or woman?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: A man as thou art.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: As I am? Hark you, sir, pray you, what kin is he to Goodman King of our parish, the churchwarden?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: No kin to him, he is the king of the whole land.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: King of the land, I never see him.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: If thou wilt dwell with me, thou shalt see him every day.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Shall I go home again to be torn in pieces with bears? No, not I. I will go home and put on a clean shirt, and then go drown myself.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thou shalt not need: if thou wilt dwell with me, thou shalt want nothing.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Shall I not? Then here’s my hand, I’ll dwell with you, and hark you, sir, now you have entertained me, I will tell you what I can do. I can keep my tongue from picking and stealing, and my hands from lying and slandering, I warrant you, as well as ever you had man in all your life.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Now will I to court with sorrowful heart, rounded with doubts. If Amadine do live, then happy I. Yea, happy I if Amadine do live.

scene.scenelocation: The camp of the King of Aragon.

stage.dir: Enter the King with a young prince prisoner, Amadine, Tremelio with Collin, Segasto, Mouse, and counselors.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Now, brave lords, our wars are brought to end,
Our foes the foil and we in safety rest.
It us behooves to use such clemency
In peace as valor in the wars.
It is as great honor to be bountiful at home,
As to be conquerors in the field.
Therefore, my lords, the more to my content
Your liking and your country’s safeguard,
We are disposed in marriage for to give
Our daughter to Lord Segasto here,
Who shall succeed the diadem after me:
And reign hereafter as I tofore have done
Your sole and lawful King of Aragon:
What say you, lordings, like you of my advice?

sp.speaker: COLL.
sp.l: An’t please your majesty, we do not only allow of your highness’ pleasure but also vow faithfully, in what we may, to further it.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thanks, good my lords, if long Androstus live
He will at full requite your courtesies.
Tremelio, in recompense of thy late valor done,
Take unto thee the Catalan, a prince,
Lately our prisoner taken in the wars.
Be thou his keeper, his ransom shall be thine.
We’ll think of it when leisure shall afford:
Meanwhile do use him well, his father is a king.

sp.speaker: TREM.
sp.l: Thanks to your majesty: his usage shall be such,
As he thereat shall think no cause to grudge.

stage.dir: Exeunt all but King and Collin.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Then march we on to court and rest our wearied limbs.
But Collin, I have a tale in secret kept for thee:
When thou shalt hear a watchword from thy king,
Think then some weighty matter is at hand
That highly shall concern our state,
Then Collin look thou be not far from me,
And for thy service thou tofore hast done,
Thy truth and valor proved in every point,
I shall with bounties thee enlarge therefore:
So guard us to the court.

sp.speaker: COLL.
sp.l: What so my sovereign doth command me do,
With willing mind I gladly yield consent.

scene.scenelocation: A room at the court of Aragon.

stage.dir: Enter Segasto and the Clown Mouse, with weapons about him.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Tell me, sirrah, how do you like your weapons?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, very well, very well: they keep my sides warm.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: They keep the dogs from your shins very well, do they not?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How, keep the dogs from my shins? I would scorn but my shins should keep the dogs from them.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Well, sirrah, leaving idle talk, tell me: dost thou know Captain Tremelio’s chamber?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ay, very well, it hath a door.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I think so, for so hath every chamber. But dost thou know the man?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ay, forsooth: he hath a nose on his face.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, so hath everyone.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: That’s more than I know.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: But dost thou remember the captain, that was here with the king even now, that brought the young prince prisoner?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, very well.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Go unto him and bid him come to me. Tell him I have a matter in secret to impart to him.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I will, master. Master, what’s his name?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, Captain Tremelio.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, the mealman, I know him very well. He brings meal every Saturday: but, hark you, master, must I bid him come to you or must you come to him?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: No, sirrah, he must come to me.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Hark you, master, how if he be not at home, what shall I do then?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, then leave word with some of his folks.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, master, if there be nobody within, I will leave word with his dog.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, can his dog speak?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I cannot tell, wherefore doth he keep his chamber else?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: To keep out such knaves as thou art!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay, by Lady, then go yourself.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: You will go, sir, will you not?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Yes, marry, will I. O ’tis come to my head, and a be not within. I’ll bring his chamber to you.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: What wilt thou pluck down the king’s house?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay, by lady, I’ll know the price of it first. Master, it is such a hard name I have forgotten it again. I pray you tell me his name.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I tell thee, Captain Tremelio.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, Captain Treble Knave, Captain Treble Knave!

sp.speaker: TREM.
sp.l: How now, sirrah, dost thou call me?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: You must come to my master, Captain Treble Knave.

sp.speaker: TREM.
sp.l: My Lord Segasto, did you send for me?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I did, Tremelio.—
Sirrah, about your business!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ay, marry, what’s that? Can you tell?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: No, not well.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Marry, then I can: straight to the kitchen dresser to John the cook and get me a good piece of beef and brewis, and then to the buttery-hatch to Thomas the butler for a jack of beer, and there for an hour I’ll so belabor myself, and therefore I pray you call me not till you think I have done, I pray you good master.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Well, sir, away. Tremelio, this it is. Thou knowest the valor of Segasto, spread through all the kingdom of Aragon and such as have found triumph and favors, never-daunted at any time; but now is a shepherd admired at in court for worthiness and Segasto’s honor laid aside. My will therefore is this, that thou dost find some means to work the shepherd’s death. I know thy strength sufficient to perform my desire and thy love no otherwise than to revenge my injuries.

sp.speaker: TREM.
sp.l: It is not the frowns of a shepherd that Tremelio fears. Therefore, account it accomplished what I take in hand.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thanks, good Tremelio, and assure thyself,
What I promise that will I perform.

sp.speaker: TREM.
sp.l: Thanks, my good lord, and in good time.
See where he cometh, stand by awhile
And you shall see me put in practice your intended drift.
Have at thee, swain, if that I hit thee right!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Vile coward, so without cause to strike a man.
Turn, coward, turn; now strike and do thy worst!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Hold, shepherd, hold, spare him! Kill him not!
Accursèd villain, tell me what hast thou done.
Ah, Tremelio, trusty Tremelio, I sorrow for thy death.
And since that thou living, didst prove faithful
To Segasto, so Segasto, now living, will honor
The dead corpse of Tremelio with revenge.
Bloodthirsty villain, born and bred to merciless murder,
Tell me how durst thou be so bold
As once to lay thy hands upon the least of mine?
Assure thyself, thou shalt be used according to the law.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Segasto, cease. These threats are needless.
Accuse me not of murder, that have done nothing
But in mine own defense.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Nay, shepherd, reason not with me.
I’ll manifest thy fact unto the king,
Whose doom will be thy death as thou deserv’st.
What ho, Mouse, come away.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why how now, what’s the matter? I thought you would be calling before I had done.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Come, help, away with my friend.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why is he drunk? Cannot he stand on his feet?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: No, he is not drunk, he is slain.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Slain, no! By lady, he is not slain.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: He’s killed I tell thee.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What, do you use to kill your friends? I will serve you no longer.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I tell thee the shepherd killed him.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, did a so? But master, I will have all his apparel if I carry him away.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why so thou shalt.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Come then, I will help. Mass, master, I think his mother sung ‘looby’ to him, he is so heavy.

stage.dir: Exeunt Segasto with Mouse bearing Tremelio’s body.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Behold the fickle state of man, always mutable.
Never at one: sometimes we feed on fancies
With the sweet of our desires, sometimes again
We feel the heat of extreme miseries.
Now am I in favor about the court and country:
Tomorrow those favors will turn to frowns.
Today I live revengèd on my foe,
Tomorrow I die, my foe revenged on me.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: No passenger this morning? What not one?
A chance that seldom doth befall!
What not one? Then lie thou there
And rest thyself till I have further need:
Now, Bremo, sith thy leisure so affords.
A needless thing, who knows not Bremo’s strength
Who like a king commands within these woods?
The bear, the boar, dares not abide my sight,
But haste away to save themselves by flight:
The crystal waters in the bubbling brooks,
When I come by, doth swiftly slide away
And clap themselves in closets under banks,
Afraid to look bold Bremo in the face.
The agèd oaks at Bremo’s breath do bow,
And all things else are still at my command.
Else what would I?
Rend them in pieces and pluck them from the earth,
And each way else I would revenge myself.
Why, who comes here with whom I dare not fight?
Who fights with me and doth not die the death? Not one!
What favor shows this sturdy stick to those
That here within these woods are combatants with me?
Why death and nothing else but present death!
With restless rage I wander through these woods.
No creature here but feareth Bremo’s force.
Man, woman, child, beast and bird,
And everything that doth approach my sight,
Are forced to fall if Bremo once do frown.
Come, cudgel, come, my partner in my spoils,
For here I see this day it will not be,
But when it falls that I encounter any,
One pat sufficeth for to work my will.
What comes not one? Then let’s be gone,
A time will serve when we shall better speed.

scene.scenelocation: A room of state in the court.

stage.dir: Enter the King, Segasto, the shepherd Mucedorus and the Clown Mouse with others.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Shepherd, thou hast heard thine accusers:
Murder is laid to thy charge,
What canst thou say? Thou hast deserved death.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Dread sovereign, I must needs confess,
I slew this captain in mine own defense,
Not of any malice but by chance,
But mine accuser hath a further meaning.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Words will not here prevail,
I seek for justice, and justice craves his death.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Shepherd, thine own confession hath condemned thee. Sirrah, take him away and do him to execution straight.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: So he shall I warrant him, but do you hear, master King, he is kin to a monkey, his neck is bigger than his head.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Come, sirrah, away with him, and hang him about the middle.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Yes, forsooth I warrant you: come on, sirrah.
Ah, so like a sheep-biter a looks.

stage.dir: Enter Amadine and a Boy with a bear’s head.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Dread sovereign and well belovèd sire,
On bended knee I crave the life of this
Condemnèd shepherd, which heretofore preserved
The life of thy sometime distressed daughter.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Preserved the life of my sometime distressed daughter?
How can that be? I never knew the time
Wherein thou was distressed; I never knew the day
But that I have maintained thy estate
As best beseemed the daughter of a king.
I never saw the shepherd until now,
How comes it then that he preserved thy life?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Once walking with Segasto in the woods,
Further than our accustomed manner was,
Right before us down a steep-fall hill,
A monstrous ugly bear did hie him fast
To meet us both: now whether this be true,
I refer it to the credit of Segasto.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Most true, an’t like your majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: The bear being eager to obtain his prey
Made forward to us with an open mouth,
As if he meant to swallow us both at once,
The sight whereof did make us both to dread,
But specially your daughter Amadine,
Who — for I saw no succor incident
But in Segasto’s valor — I grew desperate,
And he most coward-like began to fly,
Left me distressed to be devoured of him.
How say you, Segasto, is it not true?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: His silence verifies it to be true. What then?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Then I amazed, distressèd, all alone,
Did hie me fast to scape that ugly bear,
But all in vain! For why? He reachèd after me,
And hardly I did oft escape his paws,
Till at the length this shepherd came,
And brought to me his head.
Come hither, boy.
Lo, here it is, which I present unto your majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: The slaughter of this bear deserves great fame.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: The slaughter of a man deserves great blame.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Indeed occasion oftentimes so falls out.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Tremelio in the wars, O king, preservèd thee.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: The shepherd in the woods, O king, preservèd me.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Tremelio fought when many men did yield.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: So would the shepherd had he been in field.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: So would my master had he not run away.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Tremelio’s force saved thousands from the foe.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: The shepherd’s force have savèd thousands moe.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ay, sheep’s ticks, nothing else.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Segasto, cease to accuse the shepherd,
His worthiness deserves a recompense:
All we are bound to do the shepherd good.
Shepherd, whereas it was my sentence, thou shouldst die,
So shall my sentence stand, for thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thanks to your majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: But soft, Segasto, not for this offense.
Long mayst thou live and when the Sisters shall decree
To cut in twain the twisted thread of life
Then let him die. For this I set thee free
And for thy valor I will honor thee.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thanks to your majesty.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Come, daughter, let us now depart, to honor the worthy valor of the shepherd with our rewards.

stage.dir: Exeunt all but Mouse and Segasto.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, master, hear you, you have made a fresh hand now! I thought you would beshrew you. What will you do now? You have lost me a good occupation by this means. Faith, master now I cannot hang the shepherd. I pray you let me take the pains to hang you, it is but half an hour’s exercise.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: You are still in your knavery, but sith I cannot have his life, I will procure his banishment forever. Come on, sirrah.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Yes forsooth, I come. Laugh at him, I pray you.

scene.scenelocation: Another room of state in the court.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: From Amadine and from her father’s court,
With gold and silver and with rich rewards,
Flowing from the banks of golden treasuries,
More may I boast and say, but I
Was never shepherd in such dignity.

stage.dir: Enter the Messenger and the Clown Mouse.

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: All hail, worthy shepherd.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: All rain, lousy shepherd.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Welcome, my friends, from whence come you?

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: The king and Amadine greet thee well, and after greeting done, bids thee depart the court. Shepherd begone!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Shepherd, take law-legs, fly away, shepherd.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Whose words are these? Came these from Amadine?

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: Ay, from Amadine.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ay, from Amadine.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Ah, luckless fortune, worse than Phaeton’s tale:
My former bliss is now become my bale.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What, wilt thou poison thyself?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: My former heaven is now become my hell.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: The worst alehouse that I ever came in, in all my life!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Even go hang thyself half an hour.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Can Amadine so churlishly command
To banish the shepherd from her father’s court?

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: What should shepherds do in the court?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What should shepherds do amongst us? Have we not lords enough on us in the court?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Why, shepherds are men, and kings are no more.

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: Shepherds are men and masters — over their flock.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: That’s a lie! Who pays them their wages then?

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: Well, you are always interrupting of me, but you were best to look to him lest you hang for him when he is gone.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: ‘And you shall hang for company,
For leaving me alone—’
Shepherd, stand forth and hear my sentence: shepherd, begone within three days in pain of my displeasure.
‘Shepherd begone, shepherd begone,
Begone, begone, begone.
Shepherd, shepherd, shepherd.’

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: And must I go? And must I needs depart?
Ye, goodly groves, partakers of my songs
In time tofore when fortune did not frown,
Pour forth your plaints and wail awhile with me.
And thou, bright sun, my comfort in the cold,
Hide, hide thy face and leave me comfortless.
Ye wholesome herbs and sweet-smelling savours,
Yea, each thing else prolonging life of man,
Change, change your wonted course,
That I wanting your aid, in woeful sort may die.

stage.dir: Enter Amadine, and Ariena her maid.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ariena, if anybody ask for me,
Make some excuse till I return.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: What and Segasto call?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Do thou the like to him. I mean not to stay long.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: This voice so sweet my pining spirits revives.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Shepherd, well met: tell me how thou dost.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I linger life, yet wish for speedy death.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Shepherd, although thy banishment already
Be decreed and all against my will, yet Amadine—

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Ah, Amadine, to hear of banishment
Is death, ay, double death to me.
But since I must depart, one thing I crave.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Say on with all my heart.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: That in my absence, either far or near,
You honor me as servant with your name.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Not so!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I honor thee as sovereign with my heart.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: A shepherd and a sovereign nothing like.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Yet like enough where there is no dislike.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Yet great dislike, or else no banishment.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Shepherd, it is only Segasto that procures thy banishment.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Unworthy wights are most in jealousy.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Would God they would free thee from banishment,
Or likewise banish me.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Amen, say I, to have your company.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Well, shepherd, sith thou suffrest this for my sake,
With thee in exile also let me live:
On this condition, shepherd, thou canst love.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: No longer love, no longer let me live!

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Of late I lovèd one indeed, now love I none but only thee.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thanks, worthy princess, I burn likewise,
Yet smother up the blast.
I dare not promise what I may perform.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Well, shepherd, hark what I shall say.
I will return unto my father’s court,
There for to provide me of such necessaries,
As for our journey I shall think most fit.
This being done I will return to thee.
Do thou, therefore, appoint the place
Where we may meet.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Down in the valley where I slew the bear,
And there doth grow a fair broad-branchèd beech.
That overshades a well, whoso comes first
Let them abide the happy meeting of us both.
How like you this?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I like it very well.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Now, if you please, you may appoint the time.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Full three hours hence, God willing, I will return.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: The thanks that Paris gave the Grecian queen
The like doth Mucedorus yield.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Then, Mucedorus, for three hours farewell.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Your departure lady breeds a privy pain.

scene.scenelocation: Another room of state in the court.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: ’Tis well Segasto that thou hast thy will,
Should such a shepherd, such a simple swain
As he, eclipse thy credit famous through the court?
No! Ply, Segasto, ply: let it not in Aragon be said,
A shepherd hath Segasto’s honor won.

stage.dir: Enter Mouse the Clown calling his master.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What ho, master, will you come away?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Will you come hither, I pray you? What’s the matter?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, is it not past eleven o’clock?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: How then, sir?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I pray you come away to dinner.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I pray you, come hither.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Here’s such ado with you! Will you never come?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I pray you, sir, what news of the message I sent you about?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I tell you all the messes be on the table already. There wants not so much as a mess of mustard half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Come, sir, your mind is all upon your belly:
You have forgotten what I bid you do.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Faith. I know nothing but you bade me go to breakfast.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Was that all?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Faith, I have forgotten it: the very scent of the meat made me hath forget it quite.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: You have forgotten the errand I bid you do?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What arrant? An arrant knave or an arrant whore?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, thou knave, did I not bid thee banish the shepherd?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, the shepherd’s bastard?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I tell thee the shepherd’s banishment!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I tell you the shepherd’s bastard shall be well kept: I’ll look to it myself; but I pray you come away to dinner.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Then you will not tell me whether you have banished him or no?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why I cannot say ‘banishment’ and you would give me a thousand pounds to say so.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, you whoreson slave, have you forgotten that I sent you and another to drive away the shepherd?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What an ass are you! Here’s a stir indeed: here’s ‘message’, ‘arrant’, ‘banishment’, and I cannot tell what!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I pray you, sir, shall I know whether you have drove him away?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Faith, I think I have, and you will not believe me, ask my staff.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, can thy staff tell?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, he was with me too.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Then happy I, that have obtained my will.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: And happier I, if you would go to dinner.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Come, sirrah, follow me.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I warrant you, I will not lose an inch of you now you are going to dinner.—
I promise you, I thought seven year before I could get him away.

scene.scenelocation: Beside the well in the forest.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: God grant my long delay procures no harm,
Nor this my tarrying frustrate my pretense!
My Mucedorus surely stays for me,
And thinks me overlong: at length I come
My present promise to perform.
Ah, what a thing is firm unfeignèd love,
What is it which true love dares not attempt?
My father he may make, but I must match;
Segasto loves, but Amadine must like:
Where likes her best, compulsion is a thrall.
No, no, the hearty choice is all in all:
The shepherd’s virtue Amadine esteems.
But what! Methinks my shepherd is not come!
I muse at that, the hour is at hand,
Well here I’ll rest till Mucedorus come.

stage.dir: Enter Bremo looking about, hastily takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: A happy prey, now Bremo feed on flesh,
Dainties, Bremo, dainties, thy hungry paunch to fill:
Now glut thy greedy guts with lukewarm blood.
Come fight with me — I long to see thee dead.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: How can she fight that weapons cannot wield?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: What canst not fight? Then lie thee down and die.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: What, must I die?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: What needs these words? I thirst to suck thy blood.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Yet pity me, and let me live awhile.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: No pity, I! I’ll feed upon thy flesh:
I’ll tear thy body piecemeal joint from joint.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah, now I want my shepherd’s company.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: I’ll crush thy bones betwixt two oaken trees.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Haste, shepherd, haste or else thou com’st too late!

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: I’ll suck the sweetness from thy marrow-bones.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah spare, ah spare to shed my guiltless blood.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: With this, my bat will I beat out thy brains!
Down, down, I say, prostrate thyself upon the ground.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Then, Mucedorus, farewell, my hopèd joys farewell.
Yea, farewell life, and welcome present death
To thee, O God, I yield my dying ghost.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Now, Bremo, play thy part!
How now, what sudden chance is this?
My limbs do tremble and my sinews shake,
My unweakened arms have lost their former force.
Ah, Bremo, Bremo, what a foil hast thou,
That yet at no time ever wast afraid
To dare the greatest gods to fight with thee,
And now wants strength for one down-driving blow!
Ah, how my courage fails when I should strike,
Some new-come spirit abiding in my breast.
Shall I spare her? — Bremo, spare her! Do not kill! —
Saith spare her, which never sparèd any?
To it, Bremo, to it! Say again.
I cannot wield my weapons in my hand:
Methinks I should not strike so fair a one.
I think her beauty hath bewitched my force
Or else within me altered natures course.
Ay, woman, wilt thou live in woods with me?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Fain would I live; yet loath to live in woods.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Thou shalt not choose, it shall be as I say
And therefore follow me.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: It was my will an hour ago and more,
As was my promise for to make return,
But other business hindered my pretense.
It is a world to see when man appoints,
And purposely one certain thing decrees.
How many things may hinder his intent.
What one would wish, the same is farthest off.
But yet the appointed time cannot be past,
Nor hath her presence yet prevented me.
Well here I’ll stay, and expect her coming.

stage.dir: They cry within, ‘Hold him, hold him!’.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Someone or other is pursued no doubt,
Perhaps some search for me: ’tis good to doubt the worst,
Therefore I’ll be gone.

stage.dir: Enter Mouse the Clown with a pot.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: ‘Hold him, hold him, hold him!’ Here’s a stir indeed! Here came hue after the crier, and I was set close at Mother Nip’s house, and there I called for three pots of ale, as ’tis the manner of us courtiers. Now, sirrah, I had taken the maidenhead of two of them. Now as I was lifting up the third to my mouth, there came, ‘Hold him, hold him!’ Now I could not tell whom to catch hold on, but I am sure I caught one: perchance a may be in this pot? Well I’ll see: mass, I cannot see him yet. Well, I’ll look a little further: mass, he is a little slave if a be here! Why, here’s nobody! All this goes well yet: but if the old trot should come for her pot? Ay, marry, there’s the matter. But I care not, I’ll face her out and call her old rusty, dusty, musty, fusty, crusty firebrand, and worse than all that, and so face her out of her pot: but soft here she comes.

sp.speaker: OLD.
sp.l: Come, you knave! Where’s my pot, you knave?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Go look! Your pot? Come not to me for your pot ’twere good for you.

sp.speaker: OLD.
sp.l: Thou liest, thou knave, thou hast my pot!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: You lie and you say it. I, your pot? I know what I’ll say—

sp.speaker: OLD.
sp.l: Why, what wilt thou say?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: But say I have him and thou dar’st.

sp.speaker: OLD.
sp.l: Why, thou knave, thou hast not only my pot but my drink unpaid for!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: You lie like an old— I will not say, whore.

sp.speaker: OLD.
sp.l: Dost thou call me whore? I’ll cap thee for my pot.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Cap me and thou darest: search me whether I have it or no.

stage.dir: She searches him, and he drinks over her head and casts down the pot. She stumbles at it, then they fall together by the ears. She takes up her pot and goes out.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: How now, sirrah, what’s the matter?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, flies, master, flies.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Flies, where are they?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, here, master, all about your face.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, thou liest! I think thou art mad.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, master, I have killed a dung-cart full at the least.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Go to, sirrah. Leaving this idle talk, give ear to me.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How, give you one of my ears? Not and you were ten masters.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, sir, I bid you give ear to my words.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I tell you I will not be made a curtal for no man’s pleasure.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I tell thee, attend what I say: go thy ways straight and rear the whole town.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How, rear the town? Even go yourself, it is more than I can do. Why do you think I can rear a town, that can scarce rear a pot of ale to my head? I should rear a town, should I not?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Go to the constable and make a privy search, for the shepherd is run away with the king’s daughter.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How? Is the shepherd run away with the king’s daughter, or is the king’s daughter run away with the shepherd?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but they are both gone together.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What a fool is she to run away with the shepherd! Why I think I am a little handsomer man than the shepherd myself. But tell me, master, must I make a privy search or search in the privy?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why, dost thou think they will be there?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Well then search everywhere, leave no place unsearched for them.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, now am I in office: now will I to that old firebrand’s house and will not leave one place unsearched. Nay, I’ll to her ale-stand and drink as long as I can stand, and when I have done I’ll let out all the rest to see if he be not hid in the barrel, and I find him not there, I’ll to the cupboard. I’ll not leave one corner of her house unsearched, i’faith, ye old crust, I will be with you now!

scene.scenelocation: A room of state in the court of Valencia.

stage.dir: Enter the King of Valencia, Anselmo, Roderigo, Lord Barachius, with others.

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: Enough of music, it but adds to torment:
Delights to vexèd spirits are as dates
Set to a sickly man, which rather cloy than comfort.
Let me entreat you to entreat no more.

sp.speaker: ROD.
sp.l: Let your strings sleep: have done there!

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: Mirth, to a soul disturbed, are embers turned,
Which sudden gleam with molestation,
But sooner lose their light for’t.
’Tis gold bestowed upon a rioter
Which not relieves, but murders him:
’Tis a drug given to the healthful,
Which infects not cures.
How can a father that hath lost his son —
A prince both wise, virtuous and valiant —
Take pleasure in the idle acts of time?
No, no: till Mucedorus I shall see again
All joy is comfortless, all pleasures pain.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: Your son, my lord, is well.

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: I prithee, speak that thrice.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: The prince, your son, is safe.

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: O, where, Anselmo? Surfeit me with that.

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: In Aragon, my liege,
And at his parture, bound my secrecy,
By his affectious love, not to disclose it.
But care of him and pity of your age
Makes my tongue blab what my breast vowed, concealment.

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: Thou not deceiv’st me: I ever thought thee
What I find thee now, an upright, loyal man.
But what desire or young-fed humor
Nursed within the brain
Drew him so privately to Aragon?

sp.speaker: ANS.
sp.l: A forcing adamant:
Love mixed with fear and doubtful jealousy,
Whether report gilded a worthless trunk,
Or Amadine deserved her high extolment.

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: See our provision be in readiness:
Collect us followers of the comeliest hue
For our chief guardians: we will thither wend.
The crystal eye of heaven shall not thrice wink
Nor the green flood six times his shoulders turn,
Till we salute the Aragonian king.
Music speak loudly now, the season’s apt,
For former dolours are in pleasure wrapped.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Now, Mucedorus, whither wilt thou go?
Home to thy father, to thy native soil,
Or try some long abode within these woods?
Well, I will hence depart and hie me home.
What, hie me home, said I? That may not be.
In Amadine rests my felicity.
Then, Mucedorus, do as thou didst decree,
Attire thee hermit-like, within these groves,
Walk often to the beech and view the well,
Make settles there and seat thyself thereon.
And when thou feel’st thyself to be athirst,
Then drink a hearty draught to Amadine.
No doubt she thinks on thee,
And will one day come pledge thee at this well.
Come, habit, thou art fit for me!

stage.dir: He disguises himself as a hermit.

sp.l: No shepherd now, a hermit I must be:
Methinks this fits me very well.
Now must I learn to bear a walking-staff,
And exercise some gravity withal.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Here’s through the woods, and through the woods, to look out a shepherd and a stray king’s daughter. But soft, who have we here? What art thou?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I am an hermit.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: An emmet? I never saw such big emmet in all my life before!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I tell you, sir, I am an hermit, one that leads a solitary life within these woods.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, I know thee now! Thou art her that eats up all the hips and haws: we could not have one piece of fat bacon for thee all this year.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thou dost mistake me. But, I pray thee, tell me what dost thou seek in these woods?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What do I seek? For a stray king’s daughter run away with a shepherd!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: A stray king’s daughter run away with a shepherd! Wherefore, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Yes, that I can. ’Tis this: my master and Amadine walking one day abroad nearer to these woods than they were used — about what I cannot tell — but towards them comes running a great bear; now my master he played the man and ran away, and Amadine crying after him. Now, sir, comes me a shepherd and he strikes off the bear’s head. Now whether the bear were dead before or no, I cannot tell, for bring twenty bears before me and bind their hands and feet and I’ll kill them all! Now, ever since Amadine hath been in love with the shepherd, and for good will, she’s even run away with the shepherd.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: What manner of man was he? Canst describe him unto me?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Scribe him? Ay, I warrant you that I can: a was a little low, broad, tall, narrow, big, well-favored fellow, a jerkin of white cloth and buttons of the same cloth.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thou describest him well, but if I chance to see any such, pray you where shall I find you, or what’s your name?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: My name is called, Master Mouse.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Oh, Master Mouse, I pray you what office might you bear in the court?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Marry, sir, I am a rusher of the stable.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: O, usher of the table!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay, I say rusher and I’ll prove mine office good: for look, sir, when any comes from under the sea or so, and a dog chance to blow his nose backward, then with a whip I give him the good time of the day, and strew rushes presently, therefore I am a rusher, a high office, I promise ye.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: But where shall I find you in the court?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, where it is best being, either in the kitchen a-eating or in the buttery drinking: but if you come I will provide for thee a piece of beef and brewis knuckle deep in fat. Pray you take pains: remember Master Mouse.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Ay, sir, I warrant I will not forget you.
Ah, Amadine! What should become of thee?
Whither shouldst thou go so long unknown?
With watch and ward each passage is beset,
So that she cannot long escape unknown.
Doubtless she hath lost herself within these woods
And wand’ring to and fro she seeks the well,
Which yet she cannot find, therefore will I seek her out.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Amadine, how like you Bremo and his woods?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: As like the woods as Bremo’s cruelty!
Though I were dumb and could not answer him,
The beasts themselves would, with relenting tears,
Bewail thy savage and inhuman deeds.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: My love, why dost thou murmur to thyself?
Speak louder, for thy Bremo hears thee not.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: My Bremo? No the shepherd is my love.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Have I not savèd thee from sudden death,
Giving thee leave to live that thou mightst love?
And dost thou whet me on to cruelty?
Come kiss me, sweet, for all my favors past.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I may not, Bremo, and therefore pardon me.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: See how she flings away from me!
I will follow and give attend to her:
Deny my love! Ah, worm of beauty,
I will chastise thee. Come, come!
Prepare thy head upon the block.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: O, spare me, Bremo: love should limit life,
Not to be made a murderer of himself.
If thou wilt glut thy loving heart with blood,
Encounter with the lion or the bear,
And like a wolf, prey not upon a lamb.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Why then dost thou repine at me?
If thou wilt love me thou shalt be my queen.
I will crown thee with a chaplet made of ivy,
And make the rose and lily wait on thee:
I’ll rend the burly branches from the oak,
To shadow thee from burning sun.
The trees shall spread themselves where thou dost go,
And as they spread, I’ll trace along with thee.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Thou shalt be fed with quails and partridges
With blackbirds, larks, thrushes and nightingales.
Thy drink shall be goat’s milk and crystal water,
Distilled from the fountains and the clearest springs,
And all the dainties that the woods afford
I’ll freely give thee to obtain thy love.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: The day I’ll spend to recreate my love,
With all the pleasures that I can devise,
And in the night I’ll be thy bedfellow,
And lovingly embrace thee in mine arms.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: One may, so may not you.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: The satyrs and the wood-nymphs shall attend on thee
And lull thee asleep with music’s sound:
And in the morning when thou dost awake
The lark shall sing good morn to my queen,
And whilst he sings I’ll kiss mine Amadine.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: When thou art up, the wood lanes shall be strewed
With violets, cowslips and sweet marigolds,
For thee to trample and to trace upon:
And I will teach thee how to kill the deer,
To chase the hart and how to rouse the roe,
If thou wilt live to love and honor me.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Welcome, sir. An hour ago I looked for such a guest:
Be merry, wench, we’ll have a frolic feast:
Here’s flesh enough for to suffice us both.
Stay, sirrah, wilt thou fight or dost thou mean to die?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I want a weapon, how can I fight?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Thou wants a weapon? Why then thou yieldst to die?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I say not so. I do not yield to die.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Thou shalt not choose, I long to see thee dead.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Yet spare him, Bremo, spare him!

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Away, I say, I will not spare him.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Yet give me leave to speak.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Thou shalt not speak.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Yet give him leave to speak, for my sake.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Speak on, but be not overlong.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: In time of yore when men like brutish beasts
Did lead their lives in loathsome cells and woods
And wholly gave themselves to witless will,
A rude unruly rout: then man to man became
A present prey. Then might prevailed,
The weakest went to walls:
Right was unknown, for wrong was all in all.
As men thus lived in this great outrage,
Behold one Orpheus came, as poets tell,
And them from rudeness unto reason brought,
Who led by reason soon forsook the woods.
Instead of caves they built them castles strong,
Cities and towns were founded by them then:
Glad were they they found such ease.
And in the end they grew to perfect amity.
Weighing their former wickedness,
They termed the time wherein they livèd then
A golden age, a goodly golden age.
Now, Bremo, for so I hear thee called,
If men which lived tofore as thou dost now,
Wild in wood, addicted all to spoil,
Returnèd were by worthy Orpheus’ means,
Let me like Orpheus cause thee to return
From murder, bloodshed and like cruelty:
What, should we fight before we have a cause?
No, let’s live and love together faithfully:
I’ll fight for thee.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Fight for me or die: or fight or else thou diest!

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Hold, Bremo, hold!

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Away I say, thou troublest me.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: You promised me to make me your queen.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: I did, I mean no less.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: You promised that I should have my will.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: I did: I mean no less.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Then save this hermit’s life, for he may save us both.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: At thy request I’ll spare him, but never any after him.
Say, hermit, what canst thou do?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I’ll wait on thee, sometime upon the queen,
Such service shalt thou shortly have, as Bremo never had.

stage.dir: Enter Segasto, the Clown Mouse and Rumbelo.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Come, sirs, what shall I never have you find out Amadine and the shepherd?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: And I have been through the woods, and through the woods, and could see nothing but an emmet.

sp.speaker: RUM.
sp.l: Why I see a thousand emmets: thou meanest a little one?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay! That emmet that I saw was bigger than thou art.

sp.speaker: RUM.
sp.l: Bigger than I? What a fool have you to your man! I pray you, master, turn him away.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: But dost thou hear, was he not a man?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I think he was, for he said he did lead a salt-seller’s life about the woods.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thou wouldst say, a solitary life about the woods?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I think it was so indeed.

sp.speaker: RUM.
sp.l: I thought? What a fool thou art!

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Thou are a wise man! Why he did nothing but sleep since he went.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: But tell me, Mouse, how did he go?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: In a white gown and a white hat on his head and a staff in his hand!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: I thought so, it was an hermit that walked a solitary life in the woods.
Well, get you to dinner, and after, never leave seeking till you bring some news of them, or I’ll hang you both.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How now, Rumbelo, what shall we do now?

sp.speaker: RUM.
sp.l: Faith I’ll home to dinner, and afterward to sleep.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why then, thou wilt be hanged!

sp.speaker: RUM.
sp.l: Faith, I care not, for I know I shall never find them. Well, I’ll once more abroad, and if I cannot find them, I’ll never come home again.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I tell thee what, Rumbelo, thou shalt go in at one end of the wood and I at the other, and we will meet both together in the midst.

sp.speaker: RUM.
sp.l: Content, let’s away to dinner.

scene.scenelocation: The forest near the cave of the wild man.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Unknown to any here within these woods,
With bloody Bremo do I lead my life.
The monster he doth murder all he meets:
He spareth none and none doth him escape.
Who would continue, who but only I,
In such a cruel cut-throat’s company?
Yet Amadine is there: how can I choose?
Ah, silly soul, how oftentimes she sits
And sighs, and calls, ‘Come, shepherd, come!
Sweet Mucedorus, come and set me free.’
When Mucedorus, present stands her by—
But here she comes.
What news, fair lady as you walk, these woods?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah, hermit! None but bad: and such as thou know’st.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: How do you like your Bremo and his woods?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Not my Bremo, nor his Bremo woods!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: And why not yours? Methinks he loves you well.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I like him not: his love to me is nothing worth.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Lady, in this methinks you offer wrong
To hate the man that ever loves you best.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah, hermit, I take no pleasure in his love.
Neither doth Bremo like me best.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Pardon my boldness, fair lady, sith we both
May safely talk now out of Bremo’s sight;
Unfold to me, if so you please, the full discourse
How, when, and why you came into these woods,
And fell into this bloody butcher’s hands.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Hermit, I will. Of late a worthy shepherd I did love.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: A shepherd, lady? Sure, a man unfit to match with you?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Hermit, this is true, and when we had—

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Stay there, the wild man comes
Refer the rest until another time.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: What secret tale is this? What whispering have we here?
Villain, I charge thee tell thy tale again.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: If needs I must, lo, here it is again:
Whenas we both had lost the sight of thee,
It grieved us both, but specially thy queen,
Who in thy absence ever fears the worst,
Lest some mischance befall your royal grace:
‘Shall my sweet Bremo wander through the woods,
Toil to and fro, for to redress my want,
Hazard his life and all to cherish me?
I like not this!’ quoth she,
And thereupon craved to know of me
If I could teach her handle weapons well.
My answer was, I had small skill therein,
But gladsome, mighty king, to learn of thee:
And this was all.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Was’t so? None can dislike of this.
I’ll teach you both to fight, but first, my queen, begin.
Here, take this weapon: see how thou canst use it.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: This is too big, I cannot wield it in my arm.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Is’t so? We’ll have a knotty crab-tree staff for thee:
But, sirrah, tell me, what say’st thou?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: With all my heart, I willing am to learn.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Then take my staff and see how thou canst wield it.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: First teach me how to hold it in my hand.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: Thou hold’st it well. Look how he doth:
Thou mayst the sooner learn.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Next tell me how and when ’tis best to strike.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: ’Tis best to strike when time doth serve,
’Tis best to lose no time.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Then now or never is my time to strike.

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: And when thou strik’st, be sure to hit the head.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: The head?

sp.speaker: BREMO.
sp.l: The very head!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Then have at thine!
So, lie there and die: a death no doubt according to desert:
Or else a worse, as thou deserv’st a worse.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: It glads my heart this tyrant’s death to see.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Now, lady, it remains in you
To end the tale you lately had begun,
Being interrupted by this wicked wight.
You said you loved a shepherd?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ay, so I do, and none but only him
And will do still as long as life shall last.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: But tell me, lady, sith I set you free,
What course of life do you intend to take?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I will disguisèd wander through the world
Till I have found him out.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: How if you find your shepherd in these woods?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah, none so happy then as Amadine!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: In tract of time a man may alter much:
Say, lady, do you know your shepherd well?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: My Mucedorus, hath he set me free?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: He hath set thee free.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: And lived so long unknown to Amadine?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Ay, that’s a question whereof you may not be resolved.
You know that I am banished from the court?
I know likewise each passage is beset,
So that we cannot long escape unknown,
Therefore my will is this, that we return
Right through the thickets to the wild man’s cave
And there awhile live on his provision,
Until the search and narrow watch be past.
This is my counsel, and I think it best.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: I think the very same.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Come let’s be gone.

stage.dir: Enter Mouse The Clown searches and falls over the wild man Bremo, and so carries him away. Re-enters.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay soft, sir, are you here? A bots on you,
I was like to be hanged for not finding you!
We would borrow a certain stray king’s daughter of you,
A wench, a wench, sir, we would have.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: A wench of me! I’ll make thee eat my sword.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, Lord! Nay, and you are so lusty, I’ll call a cooling card for you.
Ho, master, master! Ay, come away quickly!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: What’s the matter?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Look, master: Amadine and the shepherd: O brave!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: What, minion, have I found you out?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Nay, that’s a lie, I found her out myself.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thou gadding housewife, what cause hadst thou to gad abroad,
Whenas thou knowest our wedding day so nigh?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Not so, Segasto, no such thing in hand:
Show your assurance, then I’ll answer you.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Thy father’s promise my assurance is.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: But what he promised, he hath not performed.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: It rests in thee for to perform the same.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Not I!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: So is my will and therefore even so.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Master, with a nonny, nonny no!

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Ah, wicked villain, art thou here?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: What needs these words? We weigh them not?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: ‘We weigh them not!’ Proud shepherd, I scorn thy company.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: We’ll not have a corner of thy company.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I scorn not thee, nor yet the least of thine.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: That’s a lie, a would have killed me with his pugs-nando.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: This stoutness, Amadine, contents me not.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Then seek another that may you better please.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Well, Amadine, it only rests in thee
Without delay to make thy choice of three:
There stands Segasto, here a shepherd stands,
There stands the third, now make thy choice.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: A lord at the least I am.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: My choice is made, for I will none but thee.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: A worthy mate, no doubt, for such a wife.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: And Amadine, why wilt thou none but me?
I cannot keep thee as thy father did:
I have no lands for to maintain thy state,
Moreover if thou mean to be my wife,
Commonly this must be thy use,
To bed at midnight, up at four,
Drudge all day and trudge from place to place,
Whereby our daily victual for to win:
And last of all, which is the worst of all,
No princess then but plain a shepherd’s wife.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Then, ‘God give you good morrow, goody shepherd’.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: It shall not need, if Amadine do live,
Thou shalt be crownèd king of Aragon.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, master, laugh, when he’s king then I’ll be a queen.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Then know that which ne’er tofore was known:
I am no shepherd, no Aragonian I,
But born of royal blood — my father’s of Valencia
King, my mother queen — who for thy sacred sake
Took this hard task in hand.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah, how I joy, my fortune is so good.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Well now I see, Segasto, shall not speed!
But, Mucedorus, I as much do joy
To see thee here within our court of Aragon
As if a kingdom had befallen me this time.
I, with my heart, surrender her to thee
And lose what right to Amadine I have.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: What barn’s door and born where my father
Was constable! A bots on thee, how dost thee?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thanks, Segasto, but yet you leveled at the crown.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Master, bear this and bear all.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Why so, sir?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: He says you take a goose by the crown.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Go to, sir! Away, post you to the king,
Whose heart is fraught with careful doubts,
Glad him up and tell him these good news,
And we will follow as fast as we may.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: I go master, I run master.

scene.scenelocation: Aragon. A room in state of the court.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Break heart and end my pallid woes,
My Amadine — the comfort of my life —
How can I joy except she were in sight?
Her absence breeds sorrow to my soul
And with a thunder breaks my heart in twain.

sp.speaker: COLL.
sp.l: Forbear those passions, gentle king,
And you shall see t’will turn unto the best.
And bring your soul to quiet and to joy.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Such joy as death, I do assure me that,
And nought but death unless of her I hear,
And that with speed, I cannot sigh thus long.
But what a tumult do I hear within?

sp.speaker: COLL.
sp.l: I hear a noise of over-passing joy
Within the court. My lord, be of good comfort;
And here comes one in haste.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: A king, a king, a king!

sp.speaker: COLL.
sp.l: Why how now, sirrah, what’s the matter?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, ’tis news for a king: ’tis worth money.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Why, sirrah, thou shalt have silver and gold, if it be good.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, ’tis good, ’tis good! Amadine!

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Oh, what of her? Tell me, and I will make thee a knight.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: How a spright? No by lady, I will not be a spright!
Masters, get you away, if I be a spright, I shall be so lean
I shall make you all afraid.

sp.speaker: COLL.
sp.l: Thou sot! The king means to make thee a gentleman.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why, I shall want ’parrel.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thou shalt want for nothing.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Then stand away, trick up thyself: here they come.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: My gracious father, pardon thy disloyal daughter.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What, do mine eyes behold my daughter Amadine?
Rise up, dear daughter, and let these, my embracing arms,
Show some token of thy father’s joy,
Which ever since thy departure
Hath languishèd in sorrow.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Dear father,
Never were your sorrows greater than my griefs:
Never you so desolate as I comfortless,
Yet nevertheless, acknowledging myself
To be the cause of both, on bended knees,
I humbly crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I’ll pardon thee, dear daughter: but as for him—

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: Ah, father, what of him?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: As sure as I am king, and wear the crown,
I will revenge on that accursèd wretch.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Yet, worthy prince, work not thy will in wrath
Show favor.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Ay, such favor as thou deservest.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: I do deserve the daughter of a king.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: O, impudent! A shepherd and so insolent!

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: No shepherd I, but a worthy prince.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: In fair conceit, not princely born.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Yes, princely born: my father is a king,
My mother queen, and of Valencia both.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What, Mucedorus? Welcome to our court!
What cause hadst thou to come to me disguised?

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: No cause to fear. I causèd no offense
But this: desiring thy daughter’s virtues for to see,
Disguised myself from out my father’s court,
Unknown to any; in secret I did rest
And passèd many troubles near to death.
So hath your daughter my partaker been,
As you shall know hereafter more at large:
Desiring you, you will give her to me,
Even as mine own and sovereign of my life,
Then shall I think my travels are well spent.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: With all my heart: but this.
Segasto claims my promise made tofore,
That he should have her as his only wife,
Before my council when we came from war.
Segasto, may I crave thee let it pass
And give Amadine as wife to Mucedorus?

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: With all my heart, were it a far greater thing,
And what I may to furnish up their rites,
With pleasing sports and pastimes you shall see.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thanks, good Segasto: I will think of this.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: Thanks, good my lord, and, while I live
Account of me in what I can or may.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: And, good Segasto, these great courtesies
Shall not be forgot.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Why hark you, master: bones, what have you done?

What given away the wench you made me take such pains for! You are wise indeed! Mass, and I had known of that I would have had her myself. Faith, master now we may go to breakfast with a woodcock pie.

sp.speaker: SEG.
sp.l: Go, sir, you were best leave this knavery.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Come on, my lords, let’s now to court
Where we may finish up the joyfullest day
That ever happed to a distressèd king.
Were but thy father, the Valencia lord,
With mirth and joy and great solemnity,
Present in view of this combining knot!
We’ll finish up these Hymen’s rites most pleasantly.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: Ho, lords, at the first — I am one too — but hear, master king, by your leave a cast, now you have done with them. I pray you begin with me.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Why what wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: O, you forgot, now, a little apparel to make’s handsome: what should lords go so beggarly as I do?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What I did promise thee, I will perform: attend on me. Come let’s depart.

sp.speaker: AMAD.
sp.l: We’ll wait on you with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: MOU.
sp.l: And with a piece of my liver too!
What shout was that?

sp.speaker: MESS.
sp.l: My lord, the great Valencia king,
Newly arrived, entreats your presence.

sp.speaker: MUC.
sp.l: My father?

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Prepared welcomes give him entertainment:
A happier planet never reigned than that
Which governs at this hour.

stage.dir: Enter the King of Valencia, Anselmo, Roderigo, Barachius, with others. The king runs and embraces his son.

sp.speaker: VAL.
sp.l: Rise, honor of my age, food to my rest.—
Condemn not, mighty king of Aragon,
My rude behavior, so compelled by nature,
That manners stood unacknowledged.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What we have to recite would tedious prove,
By declaration: therefore, in and feast:
Tomorrow the performance shall explain
What words conceal. Till then, drums speak, bells ring,
Give plausive welcomes to our brother king.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: How now, Envy, what blushest thou already?
Peep forth, hide not thy head with shame
But with courage praise a woman’s deeds.
Thy threats were vain: thou couldst do me no hurt.
Although thou seem’st to cross me with despite,
I overwhelmed and turned upside down thy block
And made thyself to stumble at the same.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Though stumbled yet not overthrown:
Thou canst not draw my heart to mildness.
Yet must I needs confess thou hast done well
And played thy part with mirth and pleasant glee.
Say all this, yet canst thou not conquer me,
Although this time thou hast got
Yet not the conquest neither:
A double revenge another time I’ll have.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Envy, spit thy gall,
Plot, work, contrive, create new fallacies.
Teem from thy womb each minute a black traitor
Whose blood and thoughts have twin conception.
Study to act deeds yet unchronicled,
Cast native monsters in the molds of men,
Case vicious devils under sancted rochets,
Unhasp the wicket where all perjureds roost
And swarm this ball with treasons. Do thy worst!
Thou canst not, hell-hound, cross my star tonight,
Nor blind that glory where I wish delight.
Then caitiff cursed, stoop upon thy knee
Yield to a woman, though not to me,
And pray we both together with our heart,
That she thrice Nestor’s years may with us rest,
And from her foes high God defend her still,
That they against her may never work their will.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: I can, I will.
Envy, were he never so stout,
Would beck and bow unto her majesty,
Indeed. Comedy, thou hast overrun me now
And forced me stoop unto a woman’s sway.
God grant her grace amongst us long may reign,
And those that would not have it so,
Would that, by Envy, soon their hearts they might forgo.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Nefarious hag, begin,
And let us tug till one the mast’ry win.
The council, nobles, and this realm,
Lord guide it still with thy most holy hand:
The commons and the subjects grant them grace
Their prince to serve, her to obey and treason to deface.
Long may she reign in joy and great felicity!
Each Christian heart do say ‘amen’ with me.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Comedy, thou art a shallow goose,
I’ll overthrow thee in thine own intent
And make thy fall, by comic merriment.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Thy policy wants gravity, thou art too weak:
Speak, fiend, as how?

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Why thus:
From my foul study will I hoist a wretch,
A lean and hungry neger cannibal
Whose jaws swell to his eyes, with chawing malice,
And him I’ll make a poet.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: What’s that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: This scrambling raven with his needy beard
Will I whet on to write a comedy
Wherein shall be composed dark sentences,
Pleasing to factious brains,
And every otherwhere place me a jest
Whose high abuse shall more torment than blows.
Then I myself (quicker than lightning)
Will fly me to the puissant magistrate
And, waiting with a trencher at his back,
In the midst of jollity rehearse those galls,
With some additions, so lately vented in your theatre.
He, upon this, cannot but make complaint
To your great danger or at least restraint.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! I laugh to hear thy folly!
This is a trap for boys, not men, nor such,
Especially desertful in their doings,
Whose staid discretion rules their purposes:
I and my faction do eschew those vices.
But see, O, see, the weary sun for rest
Hath lain his golden compass to the west
Where he perpetual bide, and ever shine
As David’s offspring in this happy clime.
Stoop, Envy, stoop, bow to the earth with me,
Let’s beg our pardon on our bended knee.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: My power hath lost her might, Envy’s date’s expired.
Yon splendent majesty hath felled my sting
And I amazèd am.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Glorious and wise, arch-Caesar on this earth,
At whose appearance Envy’s strucken dumb
And all bad things cease operation.
Vouchsafe to pardon our unwilling error,
So late presented to your gracious view,
And we’ll endeavor with excess of pain
To please your senses in a choicer strain.
Thus we commit you to the arms of night
Whose spangled carcass would for your delight
Strive to excel the day. Be blessèd then:
Who other wishes let him never speak.

sp.speaker: ENVY.
sp.l: Amen.
To fame and honor we commend your rest,
Live still more happy, every hour more blessed.
